title: Ticket #6402: condor_chirp coredumps when fetching a nonexistent file
description:
Michael Pelletier reports that 8.6.5's condor_chirp core dumps when fetching a nonexistent file.

This is not, technically, a bug - the chirp C API is working as designed. But it doesn't seem very useful. So we will be changing the condor_chirp tool so that it doesn't dump core when the chirp API aborts.
remarks:
2017-Sep-12 10:41:34 by mvpelletier:
It appears that this only core dumps when a destination file argument is given, as either a hyphen or a filename.

2017-Sep-14 11:25:53 by mvpelletier:
Further experimentation has identified a few other quirky behaviors which may be related to the root cause of the core dump. 

host_name --long > toput
cat toput
host_name.us.ray.com

condor_chirp put toput wasput

whoami | condor_chirp put - wasput

cat wasput

pelletm
e.us.ray.com

This behavior makes sense when dealing with data files, so you can put a field into a specific spot in the remote file, but it's not clear in the documentation that this: 

   cat file | condor_chirp put - file

... is not equivalent to this: 

   condor_chirp put file file

I thought I'd save myself some hassle by avoiding creation of a scratch file, and that's mainly when it started biting me. The core dump may have been occurring in some cases because I was treating it as if they were equivalent.

2017-Nov-09 14:26:56 by johnkn:
This is by design. the chirp c API aborts whenever it cannot perform the requested action. 

...
result = simple_command(c,"getfile %s\n",path);
if(result>=0) {
  // successful getfile
  ...
} else {
  chirp_fatal_request("getfile");
}
...
// where chirp_fatal_request is
void chirp_fatal_request( const char *name )
{
  fprintf(stderr,"chirp: couldn't %s: %s\n",name,strerror(errno));
  abort();
}

2017-Dec-11 14:54:18 by tlmiller:
Code Review

Looks good.
